            I earned both my BA and MA in Political Science from the
            University of Georgia. This website exists to host my
            various professional materials and documents associated with
            both past and ongoing research projects.
            I’ve included a number of academic articles and books on
            the “Influential Readings” page to provide an overview of
            the types of research that I regularly engage with.
            If you want to contact me, the best way to do so is by
            email.

articles.title: Influential Readings
articles.contents:
Acemoglu, Daron, & James A. Robinson. 2001. “Inefficient
Redistribution.” American Political Science Review 95(3): 649–61.



———. 2006a. “Economic Backwardness in Political Perspective.”
American Political Science Review 100(1): 115–31.



———. 2006b. Economic Origins of Dictatorship and Democracy.
Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.



Alesina, Alberto, & Howard Rosenthal. 1989. “Partisan Cycles in
Congressional Elections and the Macroeconomy.” American Political
Science Review 83(2): 373–98.



Bartels, Larry M. 2008. Unequal Democracy: The Political Economy of
the New Gilded Age. Princeton: Princeton University Press.

Demand.” Cambridge Journal of Economics 42(1): 137–53.

Learned in the Past Few Years?” Annual Review of Political

———. 2007. “From Statistical Nuisances to Serious Modeling: Changing How

Political Analysis 15(2): 97–100.



———. 2011. “Of Fixed-Effects and Time-Invariant Variables.” Political

Beck, Nathaniel L., Jonathan N. Katz, & Umberto G. Mignozzetti.

Oxford: Oxford University Press.



Bonica, Adam. 2016. “Avenues of Influence: On the Political Expenditures

18(3): 263–95.

Busemeyer, Marius R., & Torben Iversen. 2020. “The Welfare State
